original: Majjhima Nikāya 76
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Sandakasutta
analyzed: sandaka sutta
translated: With Sandaka

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kosambiyam viharati ghosita ārāme
translated: Once the Buddha was staying at Kosambī, in the Ghosita Monastery.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sandako paribbājako pilakkhaguhāyaṁ paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ pañcamattehi paribbājakasatehi.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sandakaḥ paribbājakaḥ pilakkhaguhāyam paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhim pañcamattehi paribbājaka satehi
translated: Now at that time the wanderer Sandaka was staying in the Pilakkha-tree Cave with a large assembly of about five hundred wanderers.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: Then, in the evening, the venerable Ānanda came out of seclusion and addressed the monks:

original: “āyāmāvuso, yena devakatasobbho tenupasaṅkamissāma guhādassanāyā”ti.
analyzed: āyāma āvuso yena devakatasobbho tena upasaṅkamissāma guhā dassanāya ati
translated: “Come, Venerables, let us go to the Devakata Gorge to see the cave.”

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: evam āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmataḥ ānandassa
translated: “Yes, Venerable,” they replied.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ yena devakatasobbho tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā ānandaḥ sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhim yena devakatasobbho tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then the venerable Ānanda went with a number of monks to the Devakata Gorge.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sandako paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentiyā, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sandakaḥ paribbājakaḥ mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhim nisinnaḥ hoti unnādiniyā uccāsadda mahāsaddāya aneka vihitam tiracchāna katham kathentiyā
translated: On that occasion the wanderer Sandaka was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers who were making an uproar, loudly and noisily talking many kinds of pointless talk,

original: rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ mahāmattakathaṁ senākathaṁ bhayakathaṁ yuddhakathaṁ annakathaṁ🔽pānakathaṁ vatthakathaṁ sayanakathaṁ mālākathaṁ gandhakathaṁ ñātikathaṁ yānakathaṁ🔽gāmakathaṁ nigamakathaṁ nagarakathaṁ janapadakathaṁ itthikathaṁ sūrakathaṁ visikhākathaṁ
analyzed: rāja katham cora katham mahā matta katham senā katham bhaya katham yuddha katham anna katha  pāna katham vattha katham sayana katham mālā katham gandha katham ñāti katham yāna katha  gāma katham nigama katham nagara katham janapada katham itthi katham sūra katham visikhā katha
translated: talk about kings, talk about thieves, talk about ministers, talk about armies, talk about dangers, talk about wars, talk about food,🔽talk about drinks, talk about clothes, talk about beds, talk about garlands, talk about scents, talk about relatives, talk about vehicles,

original: kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṁ pubbapetakathaṁ nānattakathaṁ lokakkhāyikaṁ samuddakkhāyikaṁ itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
analyzed: kumbhaṭṭhāna katham pubba peta katham nānatta katham loka khāyikam samudda khāyikam iti bhava abhava katham iti vā
translated: talk about villages, talk about towns, talk about cities, talk about states, talk about women, talk about heroes, talk about streets, talk about wells, talk about those departed before, talk about the diversity of the world, talk about nature, talk about the sea, or talk about whether something is so or is not so.

original: Addasā kho sandako paribbājako āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho sandakaḥ paribbājakaḥ āyasmantam ānandam dūratas uva āgacchanta
translated: The wanderer Sandaka saw the Venerable Ananda coming in the distance

original: Disvāna sakaṁ parisaṁ saṇṭhāpesi:
analyzed: disvāna sakam parisam saṇṭhāpesi
translated: and quieted his own assembly:🔽“Sirs, be quiet. Sirs, make no noise.

original: “appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha;🔽ayaṁ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako āgacchati samaṇo ānando.
analyzed: appasaddāḥ bhonto hontu mā bhonto saddam akattha  ayam samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakaḥ āgacchati samaṇaḥ ānandaḥ
translated: “Be quiet, sirs, make no noise.🔽Here comes a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, the monk Ānanda.

original: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā kosambiyaṁ paṭivasanti, ayaṁ tesaṁ aññataro samaṇo ānando.
analyzed: yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā kosambiyam paṭivasanti ayam tesam aññataraḥ samaṇaḥ ānandaḥ
translated: He is one of the ascetic Gotama’s disciples who live in Kosambī.

original: Appasaddakāmā kho pana te āyasmanto appasaddavinītā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino;
analyzed: appasadda kāmāḥ kho pana te āyasmantaḥ appasadda vinītāḥ appasaddassa vaṇṇa vādino
translated: Those venerable ones are fond of quiet, are disciplined in quiet, and praise quiet.

original: appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma appa saddam parisam viditvā upasaṅkamitabbam maññeyya ati
translated: Perhaps, if he finds our gathering quiet, he will think to approach us.”

original: Atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
analyzed: atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesu
translated: Then those wanderers fell silent.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena sandako paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ yena sandakaḥ paribbājako tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then the venerable Ānanda approached the wanderer Sandaka.

original: Atha kho sandako paribbājako āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sandakaḥ paribbājakaḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: Then the wanderer Sandaka said to him:

original: “etu kho bhavaṁ ānando, svāgataṁ bhoto ānandassa.
analyzed: etu kho bhavam ānandaḥ svāgatam bhoto ānandassa
translated: “Come, Master Ānanda! Welcome, Master Ānanda!

original: Cirassaṁ kho bhavaṁ ānando imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
analyzed: cirassam kho bhavam ānandaḥ imam pariyāyam akāsi yat idam idha āgamanāya
translated: It is long since Master Ānanda found an opportunity to come here.

original: Nisīdatu bhavaṁ ānando, idamāsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: nisīdatu bhavam ānandaḥ idam āsanam paññattanti
translated: Please, Master Ānanda, sit down on this seat. It has been prepared for you.”

original: Nisīdi kho āyasmā ānando paññatte āsane.
analyzed: nisīdi kho āyasmai ānando paññatte āsane
translated: He sat down on the prepared seat

original: Sandakopi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: sandakaḥ api kho paribbājakaḥ aññataram nīcam āsanam gahetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: and Sandaka took a low seat and sat to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho sandakaṁ paribbājakaṁ āyasmā ānando etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnam kho sandakam paribbājakam āyasmai ānandaḥ etat avoca
translated: The venerable Ānanda said to him:

original: “kāya nuttha, sandaka, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha sandaka etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “Sandaka, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished when I arrived?”

original: “Tiṭṭhatesā, bho ānanda, kathā yāya mayaṁ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatā isā bho ānanda kathā yāya mayam etarahi kathāya sannisinnā
translated: “Let be, Master Ānanda, what we were sitting talking about just now.

original: Nesā bhoto ānandassa kathā dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya.
analyzed: na isā bhoto ānandassa kathā dullabhā bhavissati pacchā api savanāya
translated: It will not be hard for Master Ānanda to hear it again.

original: Sādhu vata bhavantaṁyeva ānandaṁ paṭibhātu sake ācariyake dhammīkathā”ti.
analyzed: sādhu vata bhavantayā iva ānandam paṭibhātu sake ācariyake dhammīkathā ati
translated: It would be good if Master Ānanda would preach the Dhamma to the assembly.”

original: “Tena hi, sandaka, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi sandaka suṇāhi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: “Then listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho sandako paribbājako āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho sandakaḥ paribbājakaḥ āyasmataḥ ānandassa paccassosi
translated: “Yes, sir,” Sandaka the wanderer replied.

original: Āyasmā ānando etadavoca:
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ etat avoca
translated: The venerable Ānanda said this:

original: “cattārome, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena abrahmacariyavāsā🔽akkhātā cattāri ca anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni akkhātāni, yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ
analyzed: cattāro me sandaka tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena a brahmacariya vāsā  akkhātā cattāri ca anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni akkhātāni yattha viññū puriso sasakka
translated: “Sandaka, the one with vision, the arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One, has declared four kinds of bad conduct in regard to sensual pleasures,

original: brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariyam na vaseyya vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyam dhammam kusalanti
translated: and four kinds of futile scholastics, in which a wise person would not live the spiritual life even for the sake of a reward, let alone without one.”

original: “Katame pana te, bho ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena🔽cattāro abrahmacariyavāsā akkhātā, yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na
analyzed: katame pana te bho ānanda tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena  cattāro a brahmacariya vāsāḥ akkhātāḥ yattha viññū puriso sa sakkam brahmacariyam na
translated: “But, Master Ananda, what are the four kinds of bad conduct in regard to sensual pleasures,

original: vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti?
analyzed: vaseyya vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyam dhammam kusalanti
translated: in which a wise person would not live the spiritual life even for the sake of a reward, let alone without one?”

original: “Idha, sandaka, ekacco satthā evaṁvādī hoti evaṁdiṭṭhi:
analyzed: idha sandakaḥ ekaccaḥ satthā eva vādī hoti eva diṭṭhi
translated: “Here, Sandaka, a certain teacher holds this doctrine and view:🔽‘There is nothing given, nothing offered, nothing sacrificed.

original: ‘natthi dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ
analyzed: natthi natthi natthi huta natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam
translated: There is no fruit or result of good or bad actions.

original: vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paroloko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā🔽opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca
analyzed: vipākaḥ natthi ayam lokaḥ natthi parolokaḥ natthi mātā natthi pitā natthi sattā  opapātikā natthi loke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imam ca lokam param ca
translated: There is no present world or world beyond, no mother, no father, no spontaneously reborn beings;

original: lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.🔽Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṁ puriso yadā kālaṁ karoti, pathavī pathavīkāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati,
analyzed: lokam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti  cātumahābhūtikaḥ ayam purisaḥ yadā kālam karoti pathavī pathavī kāyam anupeti anupagacchati
translated: no brahmans or contemplatives who, faring rightly and practicing rightly, proclaim this world and the world beyond after realizing them for themselves with direct knowledge.

original: āpo āpokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṁ
analyzed: āpaḥ āpokāyam anupeti anupagacchati tejo tejaḥkāyam anupeti anupagacchati vāyo vāyokāya
translated: This person is made up of the four great elements. When one dies, the earth part reverts to earth, the water part to water, the fire part to fire, and the air part to air.

original: anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṁ indriyāni saṅkamanti.🔽Āsandipañcamā purisā mataṁ ādāya gacchanti,
analyzed: anupeti anupagacchati ākāsam indriyāni saṅkamanti  āsandi pañcamāḥ purisāḥ matam ādāya gacchanti
translated: The faculties are returned to space.🔽Four men with a bier carry off the corpse.

original: yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti.🔽Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti.
analyzed: yāva āḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti  kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti
translated: Footprints show the way to the charnel ground.🔽The bones turn white.

original: Bhassantā āhutiyo;🔽dattupaññattaṁ yadidaṁ dānaṁ.
analyzed: bhassantāḥ āhutiyaḥ  dattu paññattam yat idam dāna
translated: The offerings are mere ashes.🔽The giving of gifts is a mere human convention.

original: Tesaṁ tucchā musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṁ vadanti.
analyzed: tesam tucchā musā vilāpaḥ ye keci atthika vādam vadanti
translated: The talk of those who say there is something to be given is empty and false.

original: Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti paraṁ maraṇā’ti.
analyzed: bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedāḥ ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti param maraṇā ati
translated: Fools and wise people alike, when their body breaks up, are annihilated and destroyed, and do not exist after death.’

original: Tatra, sandaka, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: tatra sandaka viññū purisaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Now, Sandaka, a wise man reflects thus:

original: ‘ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ satthā evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhi—
analyzed: ayam kho bhavam satthā eva vādī eva diṭṭhi
translated: ‘This reverend teacher has such a doctrine and view as this:🔽“There is nothing given, nothing offered, nothing sacrificed.

original: natthi dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ
analyzed: natthi natthi natthi huta natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam
translated: There is no fruit or result of good or bad actions.🔽There is no this world or the next world.🔽There is no mother or father.

original: vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paroloko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā
analyzed: vipākaḥ natthi ayam lokaḥ natthi parolokaḥ natthi mātā natthi pitā natthi sattā
translated: There are no spontaneously arisen beings.

original: opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca🔽lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.🔽Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṁ puriso yadā kālaṁ karoti, pathavī pathavīkāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati,
analyzed: opapātikā natthi loke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imam ca lokam param ca  lokam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti  cātumahābhūtikaḥ ayam purisaḥ yadā kālam karoti pathavī pathavī kāyam anupeti anupagacchati
translated: There are in the world no ascetics or brahmins who have attained, who have perfectly practiced, and who declare this world and the next.”

original: āpo āpokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṁ
analyzed: āpaḥ āpokāyam anupeti anupagacchati tejo tejaḥkāyam anupeti anupagacchati vāyo vāyokāya
translated: ‘This person is made up of the four great elements. When one dies, earth returns and goes back to the body of earth, water returns and goes back to the body of water, fire returns and goes back to the body of fire, and air returns and goes back to the body of air.🔽The faculties go back to space.

original: anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṁ indriyāni saṅkamanti.
analyzed: anupeti anupagacchati ākāsam indriyāni saṅkamanti
translated: he approaches, he goes up to, the sense-spheres of the sky.

original: Āsandipañcamā purisā mataṁ ādāya gacchanti, yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti.
analyzed: āsandi pañcamā purisāḥ matam ādāya gacchanti yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti
translated: Four men with a stretcher carry off the corpse, the footprints disappear.

original: Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti.
analyzed: kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti
translated: The bones become bleached.

original: Bhassantā āhutiyo;
analyzed: bhassantāḥ āhutiyaḥ
translated: The offerings are wasted.

original: dattupaññattaṁ yadidaṁ dānaṁ.
analyzed: dattu paññattam yat idam dāna
translated: What has been given as a gift is lost.

original: Tesaṁ tucchā musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṁ vadanti.
analyzed: tesam tucchā musā vilāpaḥ ye keci atthika vādam vadanti
translated: The words of those who say there is something after death are vain, false, empty.

original: Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti paraṁ maraṇā’ti.
analyzed: bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedāḥ ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti param maraṇā ati
translated: Both fools and the wise are cut off when the body is cut off, are destroyed when the body is destroyed, do not exist after death.’

original: Sace imassa bhoto satthuno saccaṁ vacanaṁ, akatena me ettha kataṁ, avusitena me ettha vusitaṁ.
analyzed: sace imassa bhoto satthuno saccam a katena me ettha kata a vusitena me ettha vusita
translated: If the word of this good teacher is true, then I have done what had to be done and have lived the spiritual life under him.

original: Ubhopi mayaṁ ettha samasamā sāmaññaṁ pattā, yo cāhaṁ na vadāmi ‘ubho kāyassa bhedā ucchijjissāma, vinassissāma, na bhavissāma paraṁ maraṇā’ti.
analyzed: ubho api mayam ettha samasamā sāmaññam pattā yaḥ ca aham na vadāmi ubho kāyassa bhedā ucchijjissāma vinassissāma na bhavissāma param maraṇā ti
translated: We are equal here, having attained the same state, and yet I do not say that both of us will be cut off and destroyed when the body is cut off and destroyed, that we will not exist after death.

original: Atirekaṁ kho panimassa bhoto satthuno naggiyaṁ muṇḍiyaṁ ukkuṭikappadhānaṁ kesamassulocanaṁ,
analyzed: atirekam kho panimassa bhoto satthunaḥ naggiyam muṇḍiyam ukkuṭika ppadhānam kesa massu locana
translated: But this good teacher has gone too far in shaving off his hair and beard, in donning brown robes, and in leaving home out of faith to go forth into homelessness.

original: yohaṁ puttasambādhasayanaṁ ajjhāvasanto kāsikacandanaṁ paccanubhonto mālāgandhavilepanaṁ
analyzed: yo ham putta sambādha sayanam ajjhāvasantaḥ kāsika candanam paccanubhontaḥ mālā gandha vilepana
translated: I, who live in a house crowded with children, enjoying sandalwood from Kāsi,🔽wearing garlands, scents, and makeup,

original: dhārento jātarūparajataṁ sādiyanto iminā bhotā satthārā samasamagatiko bhavissāmi abhisamparāyaṁ.
analyzed: dhārentaḥ jātarūpa rajatam sādiyantaḥ iminā bhotā satthārā samasama gatikaḥ bhavissāmi abhisamparāya
translated: and handling gold and silver, will be equal in destiny to this teacher in the next world.’

original: Sohaṁ kiṁ jānanto kiṁ passanto imasmiṁ satthari brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi?
analyzed: saḥ ham kim jānantaḥ kim passantaḥ imasmin satthari brahmacariyam carissāmi
translated: ‘What do I know and see that I should live the spiritual life under this teacher?

original: ‘So abrahmacariyavāso ayan’ti—
analyzed: saḥ a brahmacariya vāsaḥ ayanti
translated: This is just sensual pleasure-seeking,

original: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
analyzed: iti viditvā tasmai brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati
translated: and so, being disillusioned with the spiritual life, he goes forth from the spiritual life.🔽This, Sandaka, is the first

original: Ayaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamo
analyzed: ayam kho sandaka tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamaḥ
translated: place of sensual pleasure-seeking declared by the Lord who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened …

original: abrahmacariyavāso akkhāto yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya,
analyzed: a brahmacariya vāsaḥ akkhātaḥ yattha viññū puriso sa sakkam brahmacariyam na vaseyya
translated: where a wise man certainly would not live the spiritual life,

original: vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
